DataElement.preferredDefinition: The named locations of a benign or malignant pathologic structure that affects the prostate gland.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells._The anatomic site of the tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells.

Property.preferredDefinition: The anatomic site of the tumor.

Concepts.definition: The anatomic site of the tumor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

DataElementConcept.origin: CPTAC: Clinical Proteomic Tumor Analysis Consortium
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 1/2/20 jk Released per CPTAC SME (Linda) for PRAD Baseline CRF.   7/26/19 jk revised OC concept per CPTAC input.  6/26/19 jk created for CPTAC Baseline CRFs.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A benign, borderline, or malignant neoplasm that affects the prostate gland.  Representative examples include benign prostate phyllodes tumor, prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, prostate carcinoma, and prostate sarcoma._Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This region of the prostate gland that is located between the peripheral and transition zones, surrounding the ejaculatory ducts. It gives rise to a very small percentage of prostate cancers, though these cancers are frequently more aggressive, often resulting in invasion of the seminal vesicles.

Concepts.definition: This region of the prostate gland that is located between the peripheral and transition zones, surrounding the ejaculatory ducts. It gives rise to a very small percentage of prostate cancers, though these cancers are frequently more aggressive, often resulting in invasion of the seminal vesicles.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The region of the prostate that is located most superficial and posterior as compared to the other prostate zones. It is located closest to the rectum, and is easily palpated on digital rectal exam. This zone of the prostate surrounds the distal urethra, and is the zone of origin for the vast majority of prostatic cancers.

Concepts.definition: The region of the prostate that is located most superficial and posterior as compared to the other prostate zones. It is located closest to the rectum, and is easily palpated on digital rectal exam. This zone of the prostate surrounds the distal urethra, and is the zone of origin for the vast majority of prostatic cancers.

PermissibleValues.value: Unknown: Could not be determined or unsure

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An indication that something is indeterminate or unknown.

Concepts.definition: An indication that something is indeterminate or unknown.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The region of the prostate gland that is located deep to both the central and peripheral zones; it surrounds the proximal urethra, and is the zone of the prostate gland that grows throughout life, most often causing a condition called benign prostatic hypertrophy.

Concepts.definition: The region of the prostate gland that is located deep to both the central and peripheral zones; it surrounds the proximal urethra, and is the zone of the prostate gland that grows throughout life, most often causing a condition called benign prostatic hypertrophy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term that indicates involvement of multiple zones of prostate.

Concepts.definition: A term that indicates involvement of multiple zones of prostate.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

Representative examples include benign prostate phyllodes tumor, prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, prostate carcinoma, and prostate sarcoma.:Named locations of or within the body.
